newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan to tell Rubin recovery becoming firmer - MOF.
newsitem.headline: Japan to tell Rubin recovery becoming firmer - MOF.

text.p: Japan will tell visiting U.S. Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin that its economic recovery is becoming firmer, Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka told a news conference on Friday.
Asked how he would respond to an expected U.S. expression of concern about the size of Japan's trade surplus, Mitsuzuka said:
The present state of our economy is that it is gradually recovering and the gait of the recovery is becoming steadier, he said. We will tell this (to Rubin).
The minister said he would also discuss the issue of Japan's financial system during his meeting with Rubin.
"I will tell him that we are steadily carrying out the 'Big Bang' reforms of our financial system," he said.
Mitsuzuka said that the implementation of these reforms would lead to the resolution of Japanese banks' bad loans and remove concerns about the Japanese financial system.
He said he would seek to convince the United States that Japan would achieve economic recovery led by domestic demand.
Mitsuzuka said that recent economic indicators showed that Japan's economic recovery was becoming firmer, led by private demand.
He also said that he was not overly concerned about the recent rise in Japan's car exports.
"The rise in car exports alone will not lead to a substantial imbalance of the trade account."
Asked whether the issue of foreign exchange rates would be discussed in his meeting with Rubin, Mitsuzuka said he would discuss the issue if it came up, but added:
"The foreign exchange market has been moderate recently."
Mitsuzuka and Rubin are due to meet at noon (0300 GMT).
Mitsuzuka told the same news conference that the recent fall in the share price of Nippon Credit Bank Ltd would be temporary.
He said the fall was due to NCB's plan to issue new stocks to boost its capital.
